qas.question: Which mycobacterium that causes TB can often be found in unpasteurized milk?
Which one of the tuberculosis mycobacteria is associated with the Horn of Africa?
Which of the four TB-causing bacteria do scientists think might be more common than we know?
What bacterium has the name of the country it affects most in its name?
How many M. tuberculosis complexes are there?
Which parts of Africa is M. africanum most common in?
African emigrants are not likely to get what disease in the Horn of Africa?
What form of tuberculosis has pasteurized milk caused?
Which bacterium has likely been overestimated?

context: The M. tuberculosis complex (MTBC) includes <b4_0>four<b4_0/> other TB-causing mycobacteria: M. bovis, M. africanum, M. canetti, and M. microti. <a3_0>M. africanum<a3_0/> is not widespread, but it is a significant cause of tuberculosis in parts of Africa. <a0_0><b7_0>M. bovis<b7_0/><a0_0/> was once a common cause of tuberculosis, but the introduction of pasteurized milk has almost completely eliminated this as a public health problem in developed countries. <a1_0><b6_0>M. canetti<b6_0/><a1_0/> is rare and seems to be limited to the <b5_0>Horn of Africa<b5_0/>, although a few cases have been seen in African emigrants. <a2_0><b8_0>M. microti<b8_0/><a2_0/> is also rare and is seen almost only in immunodeficient people, although its prevalence may be significantly underestimated.
